title: Letter Writing in Greco-Roman Antiquity, Library of Early Christianity

Stowers, Letter Writing, 41–2. Within the Hebrew Bible, Stowers cites 2 Samuel 11:14, 15; 1 Kings 21:8–10; 2 Kings 10:1–6; 19:9–14; Ezra 4–5. The last two passages, of course, relate Assyrian and Persian letters (and the second should be extended to 6:12). Moreover, all of the passages cited concern royal, official, or military communication, rather than the sort of cultural activity which is reflected in the New Testament

title: The Jewish Community in Ancient Rome and the Origins of Roman Christianity

Wiefel attempts to harmonize the accounts of the New Testament, Suetonius, and Dio Cassius, and in so doing may be reasoning beyond the limits of certainty imposed by the evidence. He argues that Claudius first expelled Jews from Rome (so Suetonius and Orosius) and – after many returned –attempted to prohibit their meeting in public
Bruce imagines the precisely opposite scenario: meetings were first banned, and expulsion followed (New Testament History

But the fact of a disturbance involving Jews is well established; that it had an immediate impact upon Christianity is a sound inference (cf. Acts 18:2; Cassius Dio, Roman History 60.66; Suetonius, Claudius 25.4; Orosius, Seven Books of History against the Pagans 7.6). In any case, Wiefel is clearly correct in viewing Romans as an appeal for unity to a mixed church

note: for positions in support of Bruce’s).
